column4:
I didn't learn anything new because I was pretty advanced. But I think the three things I learned outside of the little internet bubble I reside in are:
- Most people have never, ever written a line of code, used a terminal/IDE, or thought about solving their problems through an engineered solution
- The LinkedIn/Twitter bubble vastly overestimates the number of people *really* using AI at work. At best, 99% of people are just generating text, one prompt at a time. 
- Even IF 10-20% of the general population of US workers started using these advanced applications of AI tomorrow... it wouldn't change things, because most people do not have "product sense", design taste, etc.
column8: The best part about this course, is that Dan and the team treat you like an adult. They spend the first hour or so showing you how advanced users of Claude Code think about the software and how to approach problems. Then they help you install it and let you go–explicitly mentioning that if you encounter a problem or a bug, that you should try to figure it out yourself. This is perhaps the most important learning; firstly, that you *will* encounter problems (that's just the nature of engineering), and second that you should foster the curiosity and drive to solve the problems creatively. I would highly recommend this course to any professional that wants to separate themselves from the 99% of the world that are just using AI, one prompt at a time, as a glorified search engine. Instead, in just 7-8 hours, they will walk away as someone with an entirely new, powerful toolkit to build and create whatever they want.

column9:
For me personally: I'd like more concrete learning/tips/examples for using Claude Code in daily work for true end-to-end tasks rather than just demos. That's why I signed up in the first place. I liked that we started with the NPS analysis, but I was disappointed that we moved on from it after having made a few pretty reports that we didn't really QC or build from. I personally would have gotten more value from this if we'd done something like (making it up):
- still start with NPS vibe analysis (real data was great!)
- explicitly work through how to harden it (strategies to make Claude more reliable + QC efficiently)
- enrich the data with web search or other information, using parallelization to make it quicker and higher quality
- draft and refine a report and 'email to our boss' from the data working with claude to get an output we're actually happy with // good quality & not AI-isms (you could even plug Spiral as part of this)
(or some other concrete, meaty project that touches on multiple capabilities and is clearly mappable to non-technical knowledge work)

The vibe coding piece is fun, but felt quite long and we've already had lovable/replit/bolt for a while. I'm not sure how much value a non-technical audience is actually getting from trying to vibe code a web app today.

Other suggestions:
- Consider providing a brief introduction or quick-reference further reading for things like parallelization, token budget etc. - at least so people know what they don't know. Being able to run tasks in parallel is what I find game changing about cc that you don't get easily in chatbot apps. This would also help with cases where participants don't move at the same speed - people who get further can move on to more advanced material and still feel like they're getting a similar learning curve to people who've never opened a terminal before
- Version control: I get why you didn't go into git, but people still need version control if only because of wanting a safety net. If there's a workaround you can give attendees (claude.md instructions to save versions in an archive folder?) I think that will help a lot
